headline: Northeast Utilities, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2011
componenttextpreview: Good morning, everybody. We're going to be starting a few seconds. Well good morning. I know that it's early in the morning, and we really appreciate you getting here so early. I'm Vice President of Investor Relations. Speaking today will be Tom May, Chai
componenttext:
Good morning, everybody. We're going to be starting a few seconds. Well good morning. I know that it's early in the morning, and we really appreciate you getting here so early. I'm Vice President of Investor Relations. Speaking today will be Tom May, Chairman and President and Chief Executive Officer; Dave McHale, NU Executive  Vice President and Chief Financial Officer ; and Jim Judge, NSTAR's the Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer. Chuck Shivery, NU is; and the, COO were unable to join us for this conference.
 [Audio Gap] 
May be forward-looking as defined within the Safe Harbor provision of the U.S. Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. These forward-looking statements are subject to risks and uncertainties, which may cause the actual events to differ materially from forecasts and projections. Some of these factors are set forth in the news releases that NSTAR and NU issued on Friday and are in the first 3 pages of this presentation which now. If you have not yet seen those news releases or this morning's presentation, and you're on the webcast, they are up on our website. Additional information about the various factors that may cause actual results to differ can be found in our respective annual report on Form 10-K for the ended December 31, 2010 and our most recent 10-Qs, which were available as of this morning. In these documents, we our expectations how and why we use a non-GAAP measures. Now I'll turn the presentation over to Tom.

headline: Northeast Utilities, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Jeff, and thank you all for coming this morning. My job is to officially welcome you. And I was supposed to be welcoming you with Chuck. He and I were going to do a tag team and tell you how excited we are to be in the red zone with our merger. Un
componenttext:
Thanks, Jeff, and thank you all for coming this morning. My job is to officially welcome you. And I was supposed to be welcoming you with Chuck. He and I were going to do a tag team and tell you how excited we are to be in the red zone with our merger. Unfortunately, I don't feel like using both analogies today since our patriots got beat by the Giants last night. I also was going to apologize for getting you up so early in the morning, but if you have a room like I did with 7 screaming kids who are excited to see Mickey at 5:00 in the morning, you'll probably have been awake for a while also, but this is the way it goes. We do appreciate you sharing a little bit of your schedule with us today. We appreciate your interest. 
Chuck and I do appreciate not only your interest in, but your investment in our companies because in a couple of months, there will only be one. We will all be one happy family. The NSTAR investors will become part of that NU family, and so we're both looking forward to that day. So today, our team is going to talk to you on where we are, the status of our merger proceedings. I said we're in the red zone, we're getting close. And also I mention to you how our companies are doing at this stage. 
You've all heard us say this before, unfortunately, we said that a year ago and we hope that -- I think a year ago, I predicted that the merger would be complete by now. So we're a little disappointed it has taken us so long, but we all are very excited about this, and we believe that this is a compelling combination of 2 very successful companies. We think it's a little bit like peanut butter and jelly, or like 1+ 1 equals 3. We have a tremendously complementary strengths that are going to fit together very nicely. And most importantly, we're going to have the size and scale to achieve our goals. I'm really also excited about leading this new management team into the future. I think we all believe that our future is even brighter than our pasts.
And speaking about our pasts, both companies have a very strong history of earnings and dividend growth, and I think we all agree that that's very important in these days of turbulence that we've been going through in the marketplace. To have steady consistent growth is a key to making sure that we continue to have an attractive stock. Since this, hopefully, is the last time that I get to brag about NSTAR, I guess we'll be retiring that name and the New York Stock Exchange listing, which we've had for about 125 years, and I as its CEO for the last 18 years, I'd just like to say that we have operated on a very simple model. You probably all heard me say this before. We're focused on great service to our customers. We believe that translates into good, strong regulatory relationships. And you all know that relate regulatory relationships are the key to financial success on the long term.  We, at NSTAR, have enjoyed 20 consecutive years now of operating earnings growth, and we're quite proud of that. 
Our earnings picture for both companies has translated into great results for our shareholders. We've consistently outperformed our peers and the broader markets in general. For NSTAR, I know these numbers, they translate on a 10-year basis, an 11.8% annual average return, and while it's not on this chart, our 50-year return is 12.5% average annual return, which is the best in our industry or in industry for the last 15 years. Both management teams have consistently delivered for our shareholders. And so you can just imagine what this new team is going to do for you in the future. 
The merger approvals that we've been pursuing are falling in place. I won't go through all the elaborate list of all approvals we have. But we just have 2 left, the NRC and the Mass Public of Utilities. The NRC signoff we expect to occur later this month, and the DPU process will be the last one that we have left. We have finished our and reply briefs on Halloween, October 31. A little ironic, I guess. If the Commission were to deliberate and decide the case in a normal 60-day period, we could have an approval by year end. However, we do have one additional item to deal with there. There has been a DOER, Department of Energy Resource, an intervener in the proceedings that have asked the commission to consider a motion to stay the proceedings. It suggests, I guess, that the commission delay their decision on approving the merger and instead turn the merger proceedings into a proceedings. We will argue. All intervenors to get the chance to argue on November 17. We will argue that rate matters are beyond the scope of these proceedings and that we will agree to file for new rates next year when our current 7-year rate deal expires. We don't believe that the commission can actually turn a merger proceeding into a rate proceeding, but we will make our strong case on November 17. 
We present a very strong case for this merger. As you are probably aware, during the proceedings, the department changed the standard from a no-net harm standard to a net benefit standard. We presented a very strong case. David and Jim were our witnesses. So we expected the information they provide, they answered 1,000-data requests, which if I were to stack the books up, are but 10 feet tall. So there's a complete record and a very impressive record on the benefits to consumers and the environment that they will be extensive.
So before I turn it over to them, let me reiterate how excited I am about this combination and about our future. David McHale has been heading up our transition integration work and has done a great job. He tells me that our people are still excited. It's been very unique. I've never experienced anything quite like this, whether they're line men or people who are in our call centers or executives. They all stop me and congratulate me. And here it is a year later, and they're excited to be getting on what they like and moving forward. Throughout this integration process, we have gained lots of information on how each of the company does business. And David tells me that we can see lots of opportunities both to improve our service levels and reduce our costs. So we want to get on with the show. 
The combination, as I'm sure you all are aware, will strengthen our financial position and it will allow us to seamlessly on our vast infrastructure investments in capital plans. To date, the rating agencies have responded very, very well to this transaction. And as energy policy in the region, think we're larger, stronger. And we're going to be better able to help our regulators and state politicians to implement all the changes that are going to come with this new requirement of Massachusetts, the Green Communities Act. 
Before I turn it over to David and Jim, I would just like to tell you that we will not be providing guidance for the combined company today. We are, as I said earlier, in the final stages of our DPU approval process. When that's complete, I then will let the 2 of them get together and put the 2012 and further year plans together. At that time, we promise to hold an analyst day, and that will be shortly after the closing. And we will rollout our future and answer all the questions that I'm sure you want us to answer today instead. So with that, let me turn it over to David.

headline: Northeast Utilities, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Tom. Now let me add my welcome and also a little bit of welcome from Lee and Chuck. I'm sure you can appreciate that. Job number one, remain storm restoration. I know you appreciate that from Chuck's standpoint and from Lee's. They will commit
componenttext:
Thank you, Tom. Now let me add my welcome and also a little bit of welcome from Lee and Chuck. I'm sure you can appreciate that. Job number one, remain storm restoration. I know you appreciate that from Chuck's standpoint and from Lee's. They will commit to finishing the restoration effort and go every customer we still have a number of communities and a number of customers who have not been restored as of this morning. And perhaps, I would add also my household remains one of those, but that will be critically important that that's a major focus over the coming hours and coming days. But what I would like to do is provide the information that you're accustomed to seeing here both the Lee and Chuck. But I would tell you that echoing on some of Tom's comments, it's becoming increasingly outdated, if you will, to talk about the NU stand-alone story. We are on the eve of this merger, and there will be no NU standalone. there will be no NSTAR standalone. But what we have done here is to provide you the type of visibility into our capital and into our investment plan that you'll become accustomed to, but we will stop short NU standalone and what we talk about the prospects are for this company. And as Tom said, we are already looking at integrating these 2 companies operationally, strategically and thinking about how this management and leadership team come together. Now with that said, the capital plan that we have in front of you runs out through 2016, and so it's sort of a 5-year view. The cornerstone of that plan remains, for the large part, our Transmission business. And we've given the updated you not only by year, by segment but also in many respects, by project. so it's available to you and it's available by the book. It's about a $5.7 billion program overall, about $2.6 billion of which is our transmission program. I'm pleased to announce that we've added about $400 million investment spending to our transition plan and continue to invest in our distribution business. The distribution business is also very, very critical to the investment platform of this company. We will continue to invest in distribution, in the business making it as reliable as we can. We'll invest in our maintenance programs. We'll invest in the O&M and the like to drive the highest levels of that we can. There are a couple of the elements as well in the plan including some renewable spend in the Connecticut. I think you've seen earlier in the year where Connecticut pass legislation, Public Act 1180, that allows in up to 10 megawatts of renewables. it's not with respect to what technology. So I'll talk about that in a moment. 
We just drove down just a little bit with respect to transmission. These are the projects that you know and you've been following with respect to NEEWS. We are now aggressively into the first phase, as we'll talk. Northern Pass becomes and is a very, very key focus for us as well. I mentioned this earlier, $400 million of new spending driven by reliability and both on standard security, cyber security and the like, very, very critical not only for Northeast Utilities and we continue to focus on the policymaking at the FERC. We think the FERC is very supportive of transmission investment coming off the Energy Policy act of 2005. We do not see that changing. You all have seen FERC 1000. We think when ISO has done business and the way we plan to do business going forward. We are very encouraged by what we've seen from them in terms of new changes on resource allocation, on cost allocation, on transmission planning. you know talking with us in the past the ISO has a very open and very transparent planning process, the stakeholder process around cost allocation and transmission planning. We do not think that FERC 1000 will have profound impact in the way that we do business. We think it's supportive of the way we do business. 
Increasingly, you're also seeing the FERC being passed around ROEs, not so much incentives, but on the base ROE. And you may, as you follow this NU story, you may have seen recently, on September 30, a number of have filed a section 20026 complaint as the FERC challenging the base ROE, which is currently 11.14%. It dated back to about the 2006 timeframe. We feel very, very firmly that when that debate is over, which essentially will be a test of the FERC methodology that established the base ROE, that we will demonstrate, counter to the that New England rates, not only for NU and NSTAR, but all the on what that base ROE will, should be alike and inventor and in many, it's going to come down to the debate that you've seen unfold with other companies around what is the appropriate range of reasonableness and how do you measure the central tendency within that range of once you select a group of proxy companies. The has suggested that the number should not be 11.14% as it is today. It should be closer to 9.2%. we have filed sitting isn't that, you really use what is fairly FERC methodology, 11.14% as appropriate and that rates are just reasonable. 
In terms of the products themselves some, we have made tremendous, tremendous strides on the first leg of the NEEWS project, the greater Springfield reliability project is now almost 30% complete. We will drive that project through completion by the year 2013 and of the entire families here of opportunity projects, this represents more than half. So it's critically important to the driving 2012 growth into 2013, but that project now is in full swing. You'll hear us talk more and more about the second leg of this. The second leg is shown here in blue is Interstate Reliability Project. As it hits that Rhode Island, Connecticut Board our partner there is National Grid. But we plan to later this year, file citing applications in Connecticut and you will see us become more and more granular about that process that will unfold so that we can move forward and drive those investments and continue to support the reliability sites here of new England and the region. 
Following on that of course is the third leg which still needs a little bit more confirmation by the New England ISO in terms of specific projects, the specific year of NEEWS. We know that these suite of projects will be required. We are working with the New England ISO right now to confirm that data and once that date is confirmed, we'll translate that into specifically what we are building and when we are building, but we see that project which is roughly a $300 million project being required in the year 2017. I would tell you that all these projects, as we process through the course of the year with you in varies earnings calls after the change in their timing in the change in their timing and their cash patterns in terms of investments year by year it is all then refreshed and it is in your appendix right now. So if you're looking through your appendix, you will find those and sort of rebenchmark for you, including the Northern Pass project, which remains a $1.1 billion project. But as we push the timing for in-service out to 2016, we kept you current now on when year-by-year those moneys were being presented. We remain incredibly optimistic about this project. You know from conversations in the past, we feel about this is one of the most innovative ideas that we put in front of this 
[Audio Gap] 
remain very focused on the economic benefits and environmental benefits of this project, which we think is very, very carbon reduction and building a project that brings in low carbon power at market that will clear out that the mass some price, no subsidies and provide very, very attractive overall economics for the region and our customers. 
Moving on, here's both historic and a perspective view of what we stand on our transmission program. You'll recognize this chart certainly in terms of the historic perspective. A lot of that where we showed here in goal. This is southwest Connecticut projects. As you know, they're up and running, they're in service, they're generating cash flow but they are benefiting customers in a huge way with respect to the amount of congestion that our customers are no longer subjected to. hundreds of million of dollars of savings each and every day, each and every month in our customer bill. It's a very, very powerful project. Going forward, you can see that it's shift now in blue here, the non-NEEWS NEEWS and NPT project. I'm including the $400 million project of new and here is a recount policy will of the NEEWS project and of the the overall Northern Pass perspective $2.6 million going forward. And we show you later on in the appendix and some how that translates into rate base growth. 
You haven't seen this slide before, to give you a little bit more context on where we're spending capital on this plan said that New Hampshire is becoming increasingly an area of spend, strategically important to us. you can see where we have labored those in the in northern central area. And the southern areas of New Hampshire, the pockets of investment, whether it's new 115kV investment in phases, very critical that we get the reliability equation right there. Same is true of course, Berkshire and Massachusetts so we have this out for you separately. Again more detail on the appendix. Of these areas are receiving a lot of focus and a lot of attention as well in order to make sure that the system is robust, it's reliable and it is the backbone for moving wholesale power around New England as efficient as possible so that our customers are paying the best rates as possible. 
On the distribution side of the business, still very significant expenditures there. A couple of new items perhaps. One, you know from the past that we've had in our forecast investments in advanced metering, the AMI programs in Connecticut. Connecticut part of there's a new administration in Connecticut that I want to spend time understanding how AMI will benefit customers in the future and what time frame will make those investments happen. I think that likely those investments are still going to be made, but have taken them out of the forecast because I think there's more work to do. That's about the $217 million bell that. What we've also done, in part because of economic conditions, is look very carefully at the amount of new investments needed to meet new service, new customer growth and the like and no surprise, it's less. We don't see the level of customer growth that we've seen in fact, we're running under budget this year intentionally on the amount of new customer hookups and the like. I think what's most profoundly here is the amount of work we've done over the last of the year at how we're spending our money, how to optimize those money, how much technology can invest in the business to get the most return operational return off of our business. We've made great strides around reliability. We've made great strides around customer service by introducing technology. Even with respect to looking at now how those investments translated into customer favorability ratings. And I know that's going to tested by the storms both Irene and this snowstorm. but I think fundamentally, we've made making good progress there but then you year-over-year what we've said last year or even the prior versus now, you would see less distribution capital because of those reasons. Also because of extension, possibilities as we look at things like the vehicle and aging infrastructure. We think there's a very strong possibility that we'll get more life out of those assets if we are very protective of our maintenance programs, our corrective action programs and that we see as the big focus on our part day in and day out. 
Looking to the future as well, I think we see some exciting things there. This is not going to be an NU standalone future. This is going to be NU NSTAR combined company future. We are looking at the main things. On the renewable side, you know that we've investing in solar in Massachusetts. we've gone live with now with a 1.8-megawatt project. We're about to get live with our second 2.25 megawatt project, an Indian orchard. We're going to continue to invest in that phase and you'll see some capital in our plan allocated towards WMECO renewables. That's nothing you. What is new though is on the Republic Act 1180 in Connecticut, we will and have the ability to invest up to 10 megawatts. Some of that will look a lot like potentially the Massachusetts model. You'll see us shortly file a plan with the PURA and you can follow that as we proceed. But I think some of that will be in solar. Some of
 [Audio Gap] 
The past. But we still look to the future there about building additional transmission to bring renewables into the region. that has been our critical day-to-day focus over the last several months The merger has been a focus more recently of course the focus, but we're not taking our eye off our ability to really have an impact going forward, helping the region meet its renewable portfolio standard needs. 
In the middle of this page is our story around natural gas. It's a great story from an investment standpoint and from an economic standpoint. It's really a great story from our customers  There are a couple of graphics that I think demonstrates this. In terms of penetration, only about 31% of the homes in Connecticut were with natural gas. and If you stack that up against other New England states, New York and the New Jersey, it is by far the lowest degree of penetration. And we think our customers of some very, very attractive economics in front of them. And under some analysis, we suggest that it cost twice as much to heat your homes these days on fuel oil as natural gas. We are working with state policymakers on the energy side and even the federal policymakers to be thinking about driving policies towards making it easier for our customers to do the changeover. And we think that depending on those economics, we can pick up 50,000 55,000 customers, for Yankee. In fact, we could some level of expansion double the customer base of Yankee Gas alone. When you look at economics for household of say, 2,500 square feet. They spend about $3,300 a year on heating their homes. You could spend less than half of that if you converted to natural gas. Those customers who have natural gas now in their homes nut they're not heating on that, we think that's an out-of-pocket cost of $4,00 or $5,000. It's not a small amount money, but we think it's a 4 or 5-year payback. we are looking at ways to get more supply to the state. We've done that recently by the completion of our Waterbury to Wallingford project, that will bring more gas to more homes and more businesses. but we think there is the potential for that hundreds of million of dollars throughout to get natural gas to our customers. Now that said, even though we're bullish on this, we have not built that into the plan that you have in your book. So there's no vast expansion plan worked for Yankee Gas, but it's going to be a focus of ours because we think that this is a very compelling time for customers be looking to convert the natural gas. 
Let me turn our attention to now the financial. And the slide talks a little bit about NU's standalone. Obviously, we're reporting earnings as of last Friday as well. And we're very pleased with the NU financials. Our earnings year-to-date are up 12%. We continue to invest in our dividend. We continue to have a standalone ratio of about 50%. The credit conditions of this company is right now stellar and I think still improving. All that really is going to be brought to bear with the new company. So all of what you've began to understand and know about NU is still in great position, the cash flow of this company in terms of the cash flow being generated by our investment, as well as a casual being generated by bonus tracks appreciation. That will all accrue to the new company going forward and that kind of underlying strength from the capital program and the rate base program, the new you shareholders inherit all that as well. I won't dwell on this point, but when you looking at how we're doing year-to-date, and you'll hear me affirm our overall guidance 230 to 240, we are right on track. Earnings for year-to-date are up about 12.3%. Interestingly, not driven by transmission this year but driven by the distribution businesses. Even as we continue to invest in rate base growth, we have seen year-over-year increases across the board. If you peel back the onion here behind the scenes, our utilities have better now on average ROE performance than they've had in years. And that's up and down all these utilities including Connecticut. Massachusetts lag that a little bit, but if you look at the trajectory going forward a very positive story. Further behind the scene, we can have an interesting inflection point, maybe too early to tell in the third quarter around sales, whether normalized sales for the 9 months are actually half 0.5%. When we had our conference call around Q2, I shared with you that whether normalized sales were actually down about 0.5%. Our guidance was premised on flat sales, somebody asked me do see a reversal in trend normal negative or positive, absolutely not. I was wrong. It's positive and I'm not suggesting that we're seeing a trend here, but when you look at growth of the same point of growth on a non-manufacturing side in Massachusetts, we see some modest growth. in the New Hampshire, we see some positive growth. Even in New Hampshire kind of average hourly, workweek expanding little bit. We see good export growth in the Connecticut market. So there's a glimmer here and I'll be careful not to say trend wise because we are looking for longer term we still see about 0.5% load growth over the coming a half decade. 
On the guidance side, again, we'll reaffirm $230 million to $240 million consistent with Tom's remarks. We're not going to look forward as last year and share with you the standalone-s of 2012. I will affirm what we said earlier in the year about transmission. I think that's going to be on the higher side of this 105 to 110 but looking pretty good. And that's despite the fact, by the way that Hurricane Irene did take a bite of the financials just a little bit. We lost about 90 gigawatt hours of sales and there were some secondary impact including financing that storm that have taken a couple of pennies off of our earnings. 
I just want to update you quickly on the financing front. We have, every couple of months, you see us sending out a note on financing activities, but wanted to summarize this for you both on new money so you see at the top of the page and as we built our rate base and investment program has issued collectively over a $250 million of new money, I was pleased to see that the western map 10-year 3.5% coupon is as one financial Newswire reported the second lowest ever BBB category bond issuance. So I haven't scrubbed every single one of those, but I've seen at least one of the newswires report that. Either way, this is quite beneficial for our customers as we take advantage of this low-coupon environment. Also have some opportunities on the financing side as well, specifically for our around some of the tax money. As you can see we have taken out the 5.85% coupon, refied that some long dated, some short but that should set us up for; $6 million to $7 million of interest savings next year alone. So a really good play and looking forward a little bit, we got the maturity coming up for NU parent if we're to refi that today or out today, you see 7.25 % coupon could get down at substantially less. And with NU on an upward trajectory with a ratings endpoint, we are quite that NU parent has an interest savings down the road as well. 
Let me just kind of finish up by summarizing the capital program. we've shown you pieces and parts. This is not only a summary of distribution and transmission stock on top of each other, to $5.7 billion. But we compared to last year. The program in total is down from last year. It's a different time frame as 2011 is going to roll off and we introduced the 2012. A lot of that explained by distribution, a lot of that's explained by AMI. But the very focused with what's happening on the transmission space still a very good story. I want to give you some comfort that in your appendix, you have a lot of your detail to show you year-by-year how this all plays out for those of you who don't want to run back to your desk modeling. And then lastly, when you look at the rate base equivalent of that, here rate base that continues to grow to north of $11 billion. When you look at the overall compounded annual growth rate of let's say transmission as an example, that's still quite robust at 10% even updating for the year 2007 -- 2010. So I think it gives you a very good prospect and perspective on what type of growth we're going to bring to this combined company going forward and one of sort of the ankle points of this business of this merger is our ability to invest capital on behalf of our customers. At this point, let me turn the podium over to my colleague and partner Jim Judge.

headline: Northeast Utilities, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you, David. Good morning. I'm thrilled to see the crowd here. It looks like standing room only. I appreciate you showing up especially at such an early hour. As Bob both Tom and David indicated. Chuck and Lee are taking care of priority number one,
componenttext:
Thank you, David. Good morning. I'm thrilled to see the crowd here. It looks like standing room only. I appreciate you showing up especially at such an early hour. As Bob both Tom and David indicated. Chuck and Lee are taking care of priority number one, which is the final storm cleanup and restoration is in place. David did a great job  Chuck and the side which they normally cover. I'm not going to touch on 4 areas fairly briefly. The first is the third quarter results, year-to-date results for NSTAR. Second, I'm going to talk about transition projects that NSTAR has in progress. Third, most of a lot of familiar faces here, most of you are familiar with the NSTAR story, but I have 2 slides that will give you the perspective that we have on the job that we've been doing for our investors and customers. And finally, I'll wrap up with a few more insights on the merger proceeding in Massachusetts.
Earnings for the third quarter excluding merger related costs and there were actually 2 onetime items last year at NSTAR, we've excluded them. So an apples-to-apples comparison, we are $0.94 in the third quarter. That's $0.01 higher than we were in last year, it's higher than S&P liquid expectations. Despite the unfavorable weather in the third quarter, we actually had some very positive items that has an impact. Transmission revenues, contributed $0.04. We will continue to invest in that aspect of our business. We are recovering lost based revenue since we increased our spending on energy efficiency, we're entitled to recoup the revenues that are lost, spread them around the customer base. Those lost base revenues actually contributed $0.03 to the quarter, and $0.01 came from our unregulated telecommunications operations. A couple of factors that offset most positive items. We did see a 2.1% decline in sales in the third quarter, largely driven by weather. The cooling degree days were down 3% from a year ago, and so that cost is about $0.05.
And finally, interest, property taxes and higher O&M, each of those 3 items negative impact our earnings by $0.01 for the quarter. So I'm pleased with the results for the quarter, as I am with our year-to-date results, which we live on the next slide.
For 9 months, earnings for the company were to $2.12 compared to $2.07, $0.05. Several positive items, again transition revenue continues to contribute to the bottom line, gave us $0.07 year-to-date. We also experienced $0.04 pickup from the gas business, driven by a very cold first quarter. I guess sales were up 11% year-to-date. As I mentioned, this recovery of lost base revenues contributed $0.04 year-to-date to earnings, and then we have 4 letter items, each of them is worth $0.03 year-to-date. We've seen a decline in interest costs, take advantage, as David mentioned, we've advantage of the low-cost interest environment as well. Got some refinancings. We also had a lower share count this year. We had a buyback a year ago and so that contributed about $0.03 to the comparison. In 2010, we had a onetime item. That had to do with the regulatory true up of our transition charge. That was a item that we don't have this year. Again, the unregulated telecommunications business gave us $0.03. So a lot of moving pieces in there. The bottom line is earnings up $0.05 for the 3-quarter point. Those are the items. Negatively impacting them, we sold the District Energy business a year ago, so those operating earnings are no longer in the mix. O&M cost of $0.07 year-to-date and then the modest decline that we have in sales year-to-date, which is really 0.3% and depreciation of property tax combined, they cost is about $0.08. So on a combined basis, we're very -- through 9 months, we're pleased with where we are. We continue to be confident and comfortable with our standalone guidance, which is between $2.60 and $2.75 for the year. 
I want to make a couple of comments about the Massachusetts economy. When we were here a year ago, the unemployment in Massachusetts was 8.4%. Today, it's down to 4% -- 7.4%. Nationally, the trend has been positive as well, it's far less significant. The national number a year ago was 9.6%, down to 9.1% today. So and continues to improve. So recent numbers came out in terms of GDP growth, Massachusetts growth on an annual basis for the last quarter was just under 4% compared to the national numbers, which are 2.5%. I think that's the fifth consecutive quarter actually Massachusetts has outpaced the rest of the country. 
A couple of comments on transmission projects at NSTAR, we have actually doubled our transmission rate base over the last 5 years. If you look at the projects that we have on the horizon for the next 5 years, it would double again. We spent on average about $100 million a year on baseline reliability and capacity investments. We have a significant project, the Cape Cod Line that's 31-mile line, 345 kV line over the Cape Cod Canal. and hearing at the concluded back in July. In fact the briefing period has been to conclude as well in the August, so we do anticipate a decision a decision board by the end of this year or certainly early next year. Project cost is about $120 million, and again, assuming timely approval from the state, we do think that we can bring the project in by year end 2012. 
Other major projects we have is a mid-Cape project, which basically will extend the benefits of that line further down the Cape. There's some upgrading and constructing of 115 kV lines that will reduce really the load risk in the mid-Cape area. And that project is also in the regional plan. We have a new project, the Boston 345 kV connection, which basically bridges the north and south parts of the city, really to address some circuit limitations that we can foresee occurring in the near future. So that project could be in the mix over the next 2 years, and obviously, our share of the Hydro-Qu√©bec Northern Pass project that David talked about earlier, our share of that is $280 million. 
I mentioned in my comments that there's really  2 sides I want to get some perspective on NSTAR. This is on the customer's perspective. We are really a company that's driven by metrics. We have been for years. When you look at the key customer performance metrics, in the areas of reliability in things like number at length of outages, when you look at the customer service measures around meter reading, round billing, around call center performance, NSTAR has really consistently, for several years now, be a top quartile performer in our industry in every one of those measures. So it is nice to see the customer satisfaction scores really validating that strong performance. As you know, J.D. Powers conducts these customer satisfaction surveys every year, and we start improvements this year, again, on both NSTAR Electric and NSTAR gas. For NSTAR Electric, the ranking has actually improved now for consecutive year. we may be the only utility in the country that can make that claim. We ow the highest ranking of any major utility from Boston all the way down to Washington, D.C. area. NSTAR Gas, we are ranked number one in the east mid-sized utility region, kind of a similar story of steady climb since 2006. In fact the last 3 years, we've ranked number three, number two, number one. So customer demand and expectations are always increasing storms that we've experienced. But it's rewarding to see that these high scores, really reflects those strong customer commitment that we have among our 3,000 employees everyday. Well the one side on the customer story from an investor perspective is the one slide. The left slide really deals with financial performance, the right side financial condition. Our financial performance over this 15-year time period is really number one in the industry for 1.5 decade that actually reflects as CEO. Certainly, a challenging 15 years when you think back, industry restructuring 2 mergers in here, certainly several economic downturn, but we have consistently outperformed the group and outperformed the market overall. The right side shows financial conditions. Also number one in the industry, that strong credit quality is obviously allowed is continuous access to low-cost capital low-cost borrowing costs that really benefit our customers every day. This merger provides a great opportunity for us to continue that commitment to excellent customer service, to strong financial performance and to a very healthy credit quality. 
Both Northeast Utilities and NSTAR have very active energy efficiency development and implementation programs. For many years, at NSTAR, we'd spend about $50 million on energy efficiency. That stepped up to $75 million in 2009, and actually, it's been $180 million this year and over $200 million next year. Just last month, Massachusetts took the number 1 spot in the country really in terms of rankings on energy efficiency efforts. This is a national energy efficiency counsel that ranks the states and Massachusetts actually surpassed California now. We have made progress on addressing the state's renewable portfolio standards. We've executed 3 contracts at very low cost, approved by DPU, for over 100 megawatts and NU has made the commitment the merger proceedings to advance the climate change agenda. We have agreed to target increased energy efficiency. We've agreed to own and contract additional solar and to build on an electrical vehicle pilot initiative that NU has in and introduce it to the Boston area. As Tom indicated, only 2 approvals spending. We have the NRC approval, which we anticipate this month. The DPU, the hearings were completed in July. The briefing period was completed at the end of October. Typically, it's a 2-month process. We would hope for an order so we do anticipate an order within the next couple of months. The merits of our filing address these environment of concessions that we mentioned, but also get into some details in terms of those savings for customers. We have a mid-benefit analysis that anticipate customers will save $784 million over 10 years. That number goes to $5.7 billion over 40 years. That 40-year horizon is a that in the past DPU has looked at to asses the merits of merger benefits. In July, as Tom mentioned, the state agency, called Department of Energy Resources, this filed a motion to the merger proceedings. Basically, looking for supplemental information in 3 areas. Progress on the merger integration, any rate changes from the merger and more on potential climate change impacts. We trust that the DPU will deny the DOER have motion. We will have an opportunity to comment on it. Certainly, a stay would jeopardize, minimum delay today, the mini merger benefits that we've discuss with the state, benefits to our customers benefits for the states, benefits for the region. Tom indicated all arguments have now been put up to November 17th. That will allow the companies and intervenors to try to resolve issue, limit some of the issues that are pending a that motion. And after those oral arguments, we do anticipate an order out of the DPU within a couple of months. 
So some final thoughts on this last slide before we open it up for questions. We have 2 highly successful companies, very similar strategies and expertise and great opportunities ahead of us. I think we have made a very clear record before the department that demonstrates our compliance with the net benefit standard that is the rule in Massachusetts now. We have evidence, significant customer savings, significant environmental accretion and the building PATH project alone is a project -- when that project is completed, it is the equivalent of removing 800,000 vehicles off the road on a daily basis. So it's great environmental advantages of this transaction moving forward to invest if you think is combined entity combine investment opportunity. And I would like to reiterate other close that we are very enthusiastic about the merger, very confident that we will have the approvals in here over the next couple of months. We do have time for some questions. I think Jeff Kotkin should come out and join us.

headline: Northeast Utilities, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2011
componenttextpreview: We went into the year thinking that we would really reverse trend that we've seen over the last 3 to 4 years which has really been demand outright year-over-year decline. This year, the reverse trend was not to be so optimistic as to think that the econom
componenttext: We went into the year thinking that we would really reverse trend that we've seen over the last 3 to 4 years which has really been demand outright year-over-year decline. This year, the reverse trend was not to be so optimistic as to think that the economy was coming around that we didn't predict a double dip recession either. And for the first 6 months of the year, maybe the first 7 months of the year, we were sort of seeing a little disappointment relative to that. We were seeing sort of declines, whether normalize across all the classes of customers. And again, this inflection point that I discussed, we saw coming out of August and September, even in the troughs of Tropical Storm Irene is some growth and the growth was among all of our companies, all 3 customers companies and then also within each of the classes difficult into each of this quarter-by-quarter or thereabout, but when we look at this, what we say is we know there continues to be a drag on sales because of energy efficiency. So there are good things, we'll doo it the right answer to customers but it is evident more and more client organic sales. Also distributed generation. We know too that, that is moving the middle of a little bit. I saw some statistics that sort of going forward just sort of out 500,00 megawatt hours every year typically as customers are installing solar and the like. So what's driving that needle. When we looked at it, we saw that there was neutralizing for that maybe about 1% to 1.5% real growth because of economic factors that is you are seeing a little bit more manufacturing. You are seeing a little bit more consumer confidence. there was actually a tick up in New England consumer confidence. I'm not suggesting that customers as ready to start spending off their moneys but we saw that as a metric. We also prices are substantially lower from customers look at a standard offer rate right now that for many of our company including NSTAR have at a 7 handle it versus a $0.10 and $0.11 product. And that is going to put the drives on sales. So we're seeing those combination. Whether it's sustainable or not, not so sure. I said to you to the group that we look forward and look at maybe 0.05% electric growth, maybe 2.5% to 3% natural gas growth. We'll look at his pretty closely, but we do know that from a fundamental standpoint, we're going to see we're going to continue to invest in NSTAR in energy efficiency, but we will see some economic growth over the next 2 to 3 years. I don't want to get widely optimistic on that, but we do see growth emerging there.
